trans-unit.source: How to create a VNet using the Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: How to create a VNet using the Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure CLI to manage your Azure resources from the command prompt from any computer running Windows, Linux, or OSX.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure CLI to manage your Azure resources from the command prompt from any computer running Windows, Linux, or OSX.

trans-unit.source: To create a VNet by using the Azure CLI, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VNet by using the Azure CLI, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: If you have never used the Azure CLI, see [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](xplat-cli.md) and follow the instructions up to the point where you select your Azure account and subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you have never used the Azure CLI, see [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](xplat-cli.md) and follow the instructions up to the point where you select your Azure account and subscription.

trans-unit.source: Run the **azure config mode** command to switch to Resource Manager mode, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the **azure config mode** command to switch to Resource Manager mode, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, run the **azure group create** to create a new resource group, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, run the **azure group create** to create a new resource group, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output of the command.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output of the command.

trans-unit.source: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.
trans-unit.target: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource groups, visit [Azure Resource Manager Overview](resource-group-overview.md/#resource-groups).
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource groups, visit [Azure Resource Manager Overview](resource-group-overview.md/#resource-groups).

trans-unit.source: **-n (or --name)**.
trans-unit.target: **-n (or --name)**.

trans-unit.source: Name for the new resource group.
trans-unit.target: Name for the new resource group.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *TestRG*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *TestRG*.

trans-unit.source: **-l (or --location)**.
trans-unit.target: **-l (or --location)**.

trans-unit.source: Azure region where the new resource group will be created.
trans-unit.target: Azure region where the new resource group will be created.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *centralus*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *centralus*.

trans-unit.source: Run the **azure network vnet create** command to create a VNet and a subnet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the **azure network vnet create** command to create a VNet and a subnet, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output from the CLI command.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output from the CLI command.

trans-unit.source: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.
trans-unit.target: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.

trans-unit.source: azure network vnet create -g TestRG -n TestVNet -a 192.168.0.0/16 -l centralus
trans-unit.target: azure network vnet create -g TestRG -n TestVNet -a 192.168.0.0/16 -l centralus

trans-unit.source: **-g (or --resource-group)**.
trans-unit.target: **-g (or --resource-group)**.

trans-unit.source: Name of the resource group where the VNet will be created.
trans-unit.target: Name of the resource group where the VNet will be created.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *TestRG*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *TestRG*.

trans-unit.source: **-n (or --name)**.
trans-unit.target: **-n (or --name)**.

trans-unit.source: Name of the VNet to be created.
trans-unit.target: Name of the VNet to be created.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *TestVNet*
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *TestVNet*

trans-unit.source: **-a (or --address-prefixes)**.
trans-unit.target: **-a (or --address-prefixes)**.

trans-unit.source: List of CIDR blocks used for the VNet address space.
trans-unit.target: List of CIDR blocks used for the VNet address space.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *192.168.0.0/16*
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *192.168.0.0/16*

trans-unit.source: **-l (or --location)**.
trans-unit.target: **-l (or --location)**.

trans-unit.source: Azure region where the VNet will be created.
trans-unit.target: Azure region where the VNet will be created.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *centralus*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *centralus*.

trans-unit.source: Run the **azure network vnet subnet create** command to create a subnet as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the **azure network vnet subnet create** command to create a subnet as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output of the command.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output of the command.

trans-unit.source: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.
trans-unit.target: The list shown after the output explains the parameters used.

trans-unit.source: **-e (or --vnet-name**.
trans-unit.target: **-e (or --vnet-name**.

trans-unit.source: Name of the VNet where the subnet will be created.
trans-unit.target: Name of the VNet where the subnet will be created.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *TestVNet*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *TestVNet*.

trans-unit.source: **-n (or --name)**.
trans-unit.target: **-n (or --name)**.

trans-unit.source: Name of the new subnet.
trans-unit.target: Name of the new subnet.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, *FrontEnd*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, *FrontEnd*.

trans-unit.source: **-a (or --address-prefix)**.
trans-unit.target: **-a (or --address-prefix)**.

trans-unit.source: Subnet CIDR block.
trans-unit.target: Subnet CIDR block.

trans-unit.source: Four our scenario, *192.168.1.0/24*.
trans-unit.target: Four our scenario, *192.168.1.0/24*.

trans-unit.source: Repeat step 5 above to create other subnets, if necessary.
trans-unit.target: Repeat step 5 above to create other subnets, if necessary.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, run the command below to create the *BackEnd* subnet.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, run the command below to create the *BackEnd* subnet.

trans-unit.source: Run the **azure network vnet show** command to view the properties of the new vnet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the **azure network vnet show** command to view the properties of the new vnet, as shown below.
